questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department after he fell on his outstretched hand. An X-ray was performed and is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The  X-ray reveals an oblique fracture in the lower third of the radius and there is dislocation of the distal radio-ulnar joint, which is diagnostic of Galeazzi fracture-dislocation.

The patient with Galeazzi fracture-dislocation presents with pain, swelling and deformity at the lower end of the radius. On clinical examination, the disruption of the radio-ulnar joint can be elicited by pressing the lower end of the ulna. The ulna moves down and comes back like the key of a piano (piano-key sign).

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows an upward elevation of the scapula relative to the thoracic cage characteristically seen in Sprengel deformity.

Sprengel deformity is a congenital upward elevation of the scapula. It is due to the failure of the scapula to descend completely in embryonic life.

The affected scapula is smaller, shaped differently, abnormally high, and somewhat prominent. Shoulder movements are usually painless. Abduction and elevation of shoulders may be limited due to fixation of the scapula.

The Cavendish classification is used to grade the severity of Sprengel deformity. 

If the deformity is mild, no treatment is required. In severe deformity, surgery may be indicated. These procedures include:

  • Green procedure
  • Woodward procedure
  • Mears procedure

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presented to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. The radiograph of his pelvis is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis of the condition given in the picture is posterior dislocation of left hip joint.

The radiograph shows the following findings:

  • The femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • The left femoral head appears slightly smaller than the right femoral head
  • The limb is adducted and internally rotated

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with progressive swelling of his right wrist associated with a dull aching pain. The orthopedician elicits tenderness on firm palpation of the swelling. The following findings are seen on X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is osteoclastoma/giant cell tumor.

Osteoclastoma is a bone tumour with varying growth potential. It can be either benign/malignant, though it is more commonly benign. It is seen in patients who are 20-40 years of age. The commonly affected sites are the lower end of the femur, the upper end of the tibia, and the distal end of the radius.

Patients present with swelling and vague pain. Pathological fractures may also be seen. On examination, firm palpation can elicit tenderness. 

Radiologically, soap bubble appearance is seen due to interspersed lytic lesions and bone remnants. Intralesional curettage of the tumour is the common approach to management.

Other options

Option A: Chondrosarcoma is a malignant bone tumour arising from the cartilage cells. It may arise in any bone but is common in flat bones such as the scapula, pelvis, and ribs.

Option B: Osteosarcoma is a highly malignant primary bone tumor. Common sites are the lower end of the femur, the upper end of the tibia, and the upper end of the humerus. Patients present with a history of pain followed by swelling. Radiologically, periosteal reaction, sunburst appearance, and Codman's triangle can be seen. The characteristic sunburst appearance can be seen below.

Option D: Osteochondroma is a common benign tumour of the bone. The tumour stops enlarging in size once there is a cessation of growth at the epiphyseal plate. It is usually seen in adolescents who present with painless swelling around a joint, usually the knee. X-ray shows a well-defined exostosis as shown below.

questions.text: Which of the following tendons is most commonly affected in the shoulder impingement syndrome?
questions.solution:
Supraspinatus is the most commonly affected tendon in shoulder impingement syndrome. 

It is also called supraspinatus syndrome, painful arc syndrome, and swimmer's shoulder and occurs when the tendons of the rotator cuff muscles become irritated and inflamed as they pass through the subacromial space. This can result in pain, weakness, and loss of movement at the shoulder.

Causes of impingement syndrome:

  • Supraspinatus tendinitis (Common)
  • Complete or partial rupture of the rotator cuff
  • Osteoarthritis of the acromioclavicular joint

Clinical features:

  • Subacute tendinitis or painful arc syndrome: Anterior shoulder pain after vigorous activity. Treatment is with avoidance of initiating activity, NSAIDs and physiotherapy.
  • Chronic tendinitis: Recurrent attacks of subacute tendinitis and pain is worse at night. 
  • Cuff disruption: There is progressive fibrosis and disruption of the cuff leading to a partial or full-thickness tear. Treatment includes acromioplasty and repair of rotator cuff.

The following video shows the action of the subscapularis through the subacrominal space:

Related Pearl: Tests for anterior shoulder dislocation

Bryant’s test: Anterior axillary fold is at a lower level on the dislocated side.

 

Dugas test: The patient is made to place the hand on the opposite shoulder. The examiner then applies gentle overpressure on the flexed elbow to make it touch the chest. In shoulder dislocation, the elbow cannot be made to touch the chest. 

 

Hamilton ruler test: In a normal shoulder, a ruler (scale) placed on the lateral side of the arm will not touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion at the same time. In anterior shoulder dislocation, the ruler will simultaneously touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion. 

 

 

Callaway Test: The vertical circumference of the axilla is increased on the dislocated side as compared to the normal side.

The given X-ray image showing the sunburst appearance is suggestive of osteosarcoma. 

Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant tumour of the bone, with bimodal age of distribution peaking in adolescence and during the 7th decade.

The most common site involved is the distal femoral metaphysis, which mainly presents with pain and swelling. Other sites commonly involved are the proximal tibia, proximal femur, and humerus.

X-rays features include:

  • Codman’s triangle → due to new bone formation in response to periosteal elevation
  • Sunburst appearance → due to new bone formation along the blood vessels within the tumor
  • Periosteal reaction → due to the lifting of the periosteum of the bone. Periosteal reaction in osteosarcoma is irregular, unlike in osteomyelitis where it is smooth. 

Wide excision and reconstruction are preferred if the tumour is resectable and there are no skip lesions. It is done after starting neoadjuvant chemotherapy for 8-12 weeks. Chemotherapeutic agents used are doxorubicin, cisplatin, ifosfamide, and methotrexate.

Ewing's sarcoma is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after osteosarcoma. It usually occurs at a younger age and commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus. Most tumors have a balanced translocation (11;22) involving EWSRI gene and FL1 gene.

Onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is seen in radiology (as shown below) and Homer-Wright rosettes, which are round groupings of cells with a central fibrillary core may be seen histologically.

 

Chondroblastoma is a benign cartilaginous tumour occurring mainly in long bones. On X-rays, they appear as a well-circumscribed, round, or oval lytic lesion in the centre of the epiphysis of long bones with areas of calcification within the tumour. On histology presence of "chicken wire calcification" is pathognomic.

The image below shows an X-ray with a well-circumscribed, round lytic lesion in the centre of the epiphysis of the tibia suggestive of chondroblastoma.

 

Adamantinoma is a rare malignant tumour. Most cases appear in the lower extremities and classically in the tibial diaphysis. It is most often seen in the second to fourth decade of life. The patient usually presents with pre-tibial pain and swelling. X-ray shows multiple sharply demarcated radiolucent lesions in the tibial diaphysis. Microscopy shows epithelial cells in a fibrous stroma. Intralesional or marginal excision causes local recurrence so complete excision of the tumour is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient with a history of diabetes presented with swelling around the knee, restriction of movement, and minimal or no pain. The x-ray of the knee is given below. The diagnosis is _________.
questions.solution:
The x-ray depicts severe joint destruction and instability, seen on (a) varus stress (b) neutral (c) valgus stress on the patient's knee joint. There is minimal pain and this indicates a neuropathic cause like Charcot arthropathy.

Charcot arthropathy is a neuroarthropathy commonly associated with diabetes.

Diabetes is the most common cause of Charcot arthropathy, while tertiary syphilis was one of the common causes previously.

Though the exact pathogenesis of this disease is unclear, it is speculated that vascular, neurological, and metabolic changes associated with diabetes lead to this condition.

Rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, and psoriatic arthropathy present with pain.

questions.text: A patient has a history of a road traffic accident 2 years back, and has developed pain and swelling now at the same site. His X-ray image is shown in the image given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the X-ray image are suggestive of chronic osteomyelitis of the tibia.

Chronic osteomyelitis may occur by direct inoculation of the infective organism during trauma (like road traffic accident). The infection continues to thrive within the bone leading to alternating quiescent and flare up stages of chronic osteomyelitis.

The radiographic image shows oval-shaped sequestrum and periosteal new bone formation surrounding the sequestrum known as involucrum. 

The characteristic radiographic features of other conditions given are:

Osteogenic sarcoma - Sun-burst appearance, Codman's triangle

Ewing's sarcoma - Onion skin appearance

Multiple myeloma - Punched out lesions

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the condition shown in the image below?

choices.text: It can be seen on the dorsal and volar aspect of wrist

questions.solution:
Image A shows a ganglion cyst of the wrist and image B shows the surgical excision of the cyst. Image B shows a swelling that is cystic, translucent, and filled with a fluid which is suggestive of a ganglion cyst. It has high rates of recurrence and thus , option A is false. 

Ganglion cyst:

  • It arises from the leakage of synovial fluid from a joint or tendon sheath and thus contains a glary, viscous fluid.
  • It can appear anywhere in the wrist but the most common area is the dorsal surface of the scapholunate ligament.
  • Usually appears as a painless, well-defined, cystic, transillumination positive, and non-tender swelling. If there is an impingement on a nearby nerve or structure it can cause pain.
  • It disappears spontaneously, but the aspiration of the swelling or operative removal can be done for reassurance or when there is pressure on the nerve.
  • If the swelling is near the radial artery or nerves then removal is done under ultrasound guidance.
  • Even if treatment is done, the rates of recurrence are high.  

Note:

A lipoma can be a differential here but it is not a transilluminant swelling and has a positive slip sign, i.e when palpated, the edge of the swelling slips under the finger.

questions.text: A 55 year old female complains of lower backache. The radiographic image of her lumbosacral spine is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts ballooning of disc spaces leading to biconcave shape of vertebral body known as ‘Cod fish appearance’, classically seen in osteoporosis. 

It is caused due to the reduction in the strength of the bone that leads to an increased risk of fractures. WHO defines osteoporosis as a T score less than -2.5. It is the gold standard to assess bone mineral density.

Other radiological features of osteoporosis:

  • Loss of vertical height of vertebra due to collapse
  • Ground glass appearance of bones especially in the bones like pelvis
  • Loss of cortical bone (picture frame vertebrae) and trabecular bone (ghost vertebrae)
  • Loss of trabeculae in proximal femur area.

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score of -2.5 or lower, that is, a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: The knee deformity shown below is called as _____
questions.solution:
The deformity shown is genu valgum.

A normal knee has 5-7 degrees physiological outward deviation. Any increase or decrease in angle can result in knee deformities. 

Knee deformities are:

  • Genu valgus (valgum) or knock knee - Knees are abnormally approximated and the ankles are divergent.
  • Genu varus (varum) or bow knee - Knees are abnormally divergent  and the ankles are approximated.
  • Windswept deformity - Abnormal valgus deformity of one knee with varus of the other.
  • Genu recurvatum - Hyperextension at knee joint, knee bends backwards.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to your clinic with complaints of stiffness of the joints in their fingers for the past 6 years that has progressively worsened over time. On examination, the following deformity is noted. What is the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a swan-neck deformity seen in a patient with established rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Swan neck deformity is hyperextension at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint and flexion at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease of unknown etiology characterized by a symmetric polyarthritis and is the most common form of chronic inflammatory arthritis. A variation in the the HLA-DRB1 gene is known to cause RA. Cigarette smoking is known to increase the risk five to six fold.

Histopathological features include synovial cell hyperplasia and proliferation with inflammatory infiltrates and rheumatoid nodules. These are necrotizing granulomas surrounded by fibrinoid necrosis. 

RA is a systemic disease, which potentially leads to a variety of extraarticular manifestations, including fatigue, subcutaneous nodules, interstitial lung disease and pulmonary nodules, pericarditis, peripheral neuropathy, vasculitis, and hematologic abnormalities, which must be managed accordingly. 

Clinically, patients present with early morning joint pain and stiffness that relieves with activity. It mainly involves the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. Other hallmark features include flexor tendon tenosynovitis, swan neck deformity, boutonniere deformity, Z-line deformity, and trigger finger.

Patients may have elevated ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate) and C reactive protein (CRP). Rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP (cyclic citrullinated peptide) antibodies are helpful in prognosis. Progression of joint damage is assessed by plain X-ray.

Management comprises of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs for pain relief, along with disease modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs (DMARD). Methotrexate is the DMARD of choice. Hydroxychloroquine (HCQ) is given as an adjuvant in combination with other DMARDs. Biological agents such as TNF-α inhibitors, anakinra and rituximab are known to reduce the signs and symptoms of RA, slow radiographic progression of joint damage, and improve physical function and quality of life.

Other options:

Option A- Osteoarthritis(OA) typically affects the weight-bearing joints like the knee, hip, and spine. It presents bilaterally with pain being the predominant symptom. The pain worsens with use. Other symptoms such as joint stiffness, swelling, giving away or locking can be present.

Option B- Gout has typical features of pain, swelling, and warmth of the first metatarsophalangeal joint. The radiograph is normal in the initial stages while it shows erosions, punched-out lesions, and sclerosis with preservation of joint space in the late stages.

Option C- Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory musculoskeletal disease characteristically occurring in individuals with psoriasis.  Psoriatic arthritis of the hands commonly involves proximal and distal interphalangeal joints (PIP, DIP) and metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP). The distal interphalangeal joint (DIP) is the most common joint involved in psoriatic arthritis. X-ray shows a characteristic pencil-in-cup appearance.

questions.text: A throw ball player presents to the emergency room with pain over the shoulder, arm abducted and externally rotated and loss of sensation over the proximal lateral aspect of the arm. Which of the following nerve injuries is likely associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation is suggestive of anterior dislocation of shoulder. The most common nerve injured in these cases is the axillary nerve as it winds around the humerus.

In axillary nerve injury, there is loss of sensation over a small part of the deltoid region in upper arm (regimental badge area) and weakness in abduction (15-90 degress) due to denervation of deltoid. Overhead abduction is unaffected as it is the function of serratus anterior and trapezius muscles.

questions.text: A patient who had applied plaster to his right leg for a tibial shaft fracture ,now presents with severe pain in the leg. On examination, the distal pulses are absent, on passive stretching the pain increases, and on opening the plaster, the leg appears edematous and numerous blisters are seen. Considering the suspected diagnosis, what would be the most appropriate management in this case?

choices.text: Opening of the plaster is sufficient

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests acute compartment syndrome, and it is treated immediately with fasciotomy.

The classic features of ischemia in acute compartment syndrome include the 5 Ps:

  • Pain: Pain is the first symptom of acute compartment syndrome. Ischemic muscle is highly sensitive to touch. On the passive stretching of the muscles, severe pain can be elicited. 
  • Paresthesia: Paresthesia and hypoesthesia may be noted due to compression of nerves traversing the affected compartment. They are the first signs of nerve ischemia.
  • Pallor: Pallor of the skin may not always be seen. The skin outside the compartment may be normally perfused, as only the intra-compartmental perfusion may be affected.
  • Paralysis: Paralysis of muscle groups affected in that compartment is a late sign.
  • Pulselessness: Usually, the peripheral pulses and capillary return are intact in the early stages, unless there is a major arterial injury. If pulses are absent, arteriography is indicated. 

The diagnosis can be confirmed by measuring the intra-compartmental pressure using a split catheter introduced into the compartment. The difference between diastolic pressure and compartment pressure is known as the differential pressure (ΔP). A differential pressure (ΔP) of less than 30 mm Hg (4.00 kilopascals) is an indication for immediate compartment decompression.

Treatment: The threatened compartment must be promptly decompressed, merely splitting the plaster is utterly useless and the limb must be nursed flat, elevating the limb causes further decrease in end capillary pressure and aggravates the muscle ischemia. In the case of compartment syndrome in the leg, Fasciotomy means opening all four compartments. Wounds to be left open and inspected 2 days later, if tissues are healthy, the wounds can be sutured. If there is muscle necrosis, debridement to be carried out.

questions.text: Shepherd's crook deformity is seen in ______
questions.solution:
Shepherd's crook deformity is seen in fibrous dysplasia of proximal femur.

Fibrous dysplasia is a developmental disorder in which area of trabecular bone is replaced by cellular fibrous tissue. If this occurs in the weight-bearing bones like the femur, it will lead to the bending of bones called as ‘Shepherd’s crook' deformity.

Image: Bending of upper femur in fibrous dysplasia known as Shepherd’s crook deformity

questions.text: A patient was admitted to ICU 48 hours after the fracture of the femur. The saturation of oxygen in the rebreathing unit was 100% but his Spo2 remained 60%. The patient is in a state of confusion. Chest radiograph showed lung fields to be clear. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the above clinical scenario is a fat embolism. Presence of respiratory insufficiency and altered mental status following a long bone fracture (fracture of the femur) favours the diagnosis.

Fat embolism syndrome results from the presence of numerous fat emboli within the microcirculation. It most commonly occurs after the fracture of the long bone or pelvis. They present with non-specific symptoms like tachypnea, tachycardia and fever that manifest within 24- 48 hours after the injury. Damage to the microvasculature of various organs leads to :

  • Mild hypoxia to rapidly progressing respiratory failure.
  • Depression of the central nervous system.
  • Petechial rashes
  • Hemorrhagic lesions of the retina.

questions.text: While examining a patient with a right forearm fracture, you ask him to make a fist. The following finding is noted during this procedure. What is the sign called as ?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the pointing index sign and is associated with median nerve injury at the forearm or elbow.

The pointing index sign is seen in supracondylar fractures of the humerus.

This finding occurs as a result of injury to the anterior interosseous nerve, a branch of the median nerve. It results in the loss of function of both flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) and flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS). Hence, the index finger sticks out when the patient is asked to clasp their hand. 

Other options:

Option A:  In Froment's sign, due to the weakness of the adductor pollicis muscle, the adduction of the thumb is lost. When asked to hold an object, the patient tries to hold the object by using the flexor pollicis longus muscle. This produces flexion at the interphalangeal joint while holding the book.

Option C:  Paralysis of flexor pollicis brevis can occur in median nerve injury at the arm and elbow. Benediction hand sign (attempt to make a fist gives pointed index and middle finger) and Ochsner's clasping test (attempt to clasp both hands show pointing index finger) are used to test such injuries.

Option D:  Policeman tip deformity, also known as waiter's tip hand or porter's tip hand, is a finding of Erb's palsy due to injury of the upper trunk of the brachial plexus involving C5 and C6. The hand is adducted, medially rotated, and hangs by the side with the elbow extended and pronated.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a gradually progressing swelling and pain for 6 months over the upper tibia. His radiographic image is shown below. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young boy having gradually progressive pain and swelling and the radiographic image showing a well-defined lytic lesion with a dense sclerotic rim are most suggestive of Brodie's abscess.

Brodie's abscess is a localized form of subacute osteomyelitis that occurs most often in the long bones of the lower extremities of young adults. The organism most involved would be Staphylococcus aureus. It usually presents with intermittent pain that lasts long and local tenderness over the affected area.

Treatment:

  • Immobilization and antibiotics (flucloxacillin and fusidic acid) intravenous for 4-5 days, followed by oral administration for another 6 weeks; healing may take up to 12 months
  • Curettage is needed if the X-rays show no healing after conservative management.
  • Curettage is also done along with open biopsy in doubtful cases.

All of the given conditions may present with a history of swelling and pain. However, the differentiating features of each of the given conditions are as follows:

Condition Age group Radiographic findings
Brodie's abscess

Children, adolescents

 A lytic lesion with a dense sclerotic rim, minimal periosteal reaction
Osteosarcoma Children, adolescents, and seventh decade Periosteal reaction leading to sunray appearance and Codman triangle
Osteoclastoma 20-40 years A lytic lesion with a thin sclerotic rim, minimal periosteal reaction
Ewing's sarcoma 10-20 years Periosteal reaction leading to onion peel appearance
